M.G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: This Complaint is brought pursuant to M.G.L. c. 208, § 28, applicable to custody modifications, as interpreted by Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006), Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996), and related authorities.

M.G.L. c. 208, \u00a7\u00a7 28 & 30.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction pursuant to M.G.L. c. 208, §§ 28 & 30, M.G.L. c. 209C, § 20, and M.G.L. c. 215, § 6, granting the Probate and Family Court authority to modify prior custody and visitation orders when material changes in circumstances affecting the welfare of a minor child occur.

M.G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 20.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction pursuant to M.G.L. c. 208, §§ 28 & 30, M.G.L. c. 209C, § 20, and M.G.L. c. 215, § 6, granting the Probate and Family Court authority to modify prior custody and visitation orders when material changes in circumstances affecting the welfare of a minor child occur.

M.G.L. c. 215, \u00a7 6.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction pursuant to M.G.L. c. 208, §§ 28 & 30, M.G.L. c. 209C, § 20, and M.G.L. c. 215, § 6, granting the Probate and Family Court authority to modify prior custody and visitation orders when material changes in circumstances affecting the welfare of a minor child occur.

Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).proposition: This Complaint is brought pursuant to M.G.L. c. 208, § 28, applicable to custody modifications, as interpreted by Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006), Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996), and related authorities.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).support_reasoning: The proposition concerns M.G.L. c. 208, § 28 and custody modifications, but Mason v. Coleman is a removal/relocation case decided under M.G.L. c. 208, § 30, not § 28. While the case discusses best interests and joint physical custody in the context of one parent’s attempted relocation, it does not interpret or apply § 28’s standards for modification of custody judgments. Thus, Mason is not direct authority for a complaint brought “pursuant to c. 208, § 28” on custody modification grounds, though it may be tangentially relevant to best‑interest analysis where joint custody and relocation are involved.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 208, § 30, governs removal from the Commonwealth of children of divorced parents where one of the parents seeks to relocate without the consent of the other parent. … We conclude that in such a situation ‘cause shown’ pursuant to G. L. c. 208, § 30, means a showing that removal is in the ‘best interests’ of the children taking into account all the circumstances and weighing the factors as described below.”

Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).proposition: This Complaint is brought pursuant to M.G.L. c. 208, § 28, applicable to custody modifications, as interpreted by Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006), Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996), and related authorities.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).support_reasoning: Custody of Vaughn discusses custody determinations and expressly interprets and applies G.L. c. 208, § 31, not § 28. The opinion focuses on the need for explicit findings about domestic violence and its effects in custody awards, and references statutory requirements for written findings when a 209A order exists, but it does not construe or apply § 28 or the standard for custody modifications under that section. Thus, citing Vaughn as an interpretation of § 28 is inaccurate, even though it is relevant more broadly to custody and domestic violence considerations.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).relevant_excerpt: “The Legislature reached a similar conclusion in respect to shared legal or physical custody. General Laws c. 208, § 31, provides that ‘[i]f, despite the prior or current issuance of a restraining order against one parent pursuant to chapter two hundred and nine A, the court orders shared legal or physical custody . . . the court shall provide written findings to support such shared custody order.’ A G. L. c. 209A order was outstanding in this case, and the judge made no explicit findings regarding the effect of shared custody on the child.”

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).proposition: The proposed relocation and increased travel burden frustrate the intent of the prior order and require modification to preserve the child’s welfare and continued adherence to Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003), emphasizing the centrality of the child’s best interests.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).support_reasoning: The case does not involve a relocation request or increased travel burden after an existing custody order, nor does it hold that such relocation that frustrates a prior order requires modification. Custody of Kali is a first-instance custody allocation case under G.L. c. 209C, § 10(a), focused on the best interests standard and stability of existing arrangements, not on modification due to relocation. While the opinion strongly emphasizes the child’s best interests and stability, it does not provide authority for the specific proposition that relocation and added travel burdens, by frustrating the intent of a prior order, require modification of that order.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).relevant_excerpt: “The statute gives direction to the judge’s consideration of a child’s ‘best interests’ by ‘evincing a general intent on the part of the Legislature to maintain the bonds between the child and her caregiver.’ … If the parenting arrangement in which a child has lived is satisfactory and is reasonably capable of preservation, it is ordinarily in the child’s best interests to maintain that arrangement, and contrary to the child’s best interest to disrupt it. Stability is itself of enormous benefit to a child, and any unnecessary tampering with the status quo simply increases the risk of harm to the child.”

Murray v. Super, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146 (.raw_text: Murray v. Super, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146 (2015)
Murray v. Super, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146 (.proposition: The Massachusetts courts have long recognized relocation or distance‑based conflicts as material changes in circumstances justifying modification.
Murray v. Super, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146 (.support_reasoning: The opinion clearly deals with a relocation/removal dispute, but it does so in the context of an initial removal request under G.L. c. 208, § 30, not as a complaint to modify an existing custody or parenting-time order based on a post‑judgment relocation or distance‑based conflict. The court applies the Yannas ‘real advantage’ removal framework and discusses balancing interests, but it does not characterize relocation itself as a ‘material change in circumstances’ warranting modification, nor does it discuss the long‑standing recognition of relocation as such a basis for modification. Thus it does not directly support the specific proposition about ‘material change’ for modification purposes.
Murray v. Super, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146 (.relevant_excerpt: “The removal from the Commonwealth of children of divorced parents is governed generally by G. L. c. 208, § 30… In determining whether cause for removal by the parent with primary physical custody has been shown under the statute, the judge must consider the custodial parent’s request under the familiar two-prong ‘real advantage’ test set forth in Yannas… and Hale… ‘[T]he first consideration is whether there is a good reason for the move, a ‘real advantage.’ Second, if the real advantage test is satisfied, the judge must consider whether the move is in the best interests of the children.’”}

Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.proposition: A modification is therefore necessary to align the parenting schedule with the child’s schooling, stability, and emotional wellbeing, consistent with Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704 (1985), and Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257 (2001).
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.support_reasoning: Yannas concerns removal of children from the Commonwealth by a custodial parent and articulates the “real advantage”/best-interests standard for relocation, not modification of a parenting schedule to align with schooling, stability, and emotional wellbeing. While the opinion discusses best interests generally, it is in the context of relocation and custodial parent’s move, not post-judgment schedule modification tied to school and routine. Thus, citing Yannas specifically for the need to modify a parenting schedule to match school and stability overstates and mischaracterizes its holding.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.relevant_excerpt: “An evaluation of the best interests of the child requires attention to whether the quality of the child’s life may be improved by the change (including any improvement flowing from an improvement in the quality of the custodial parent’s life), the possible adverse effect of the elimination or curtailment of the child’s association with the noncustodial parent, and the extent to which moving or not moving will affect the emotional, physical, or developmental needs of the child.”

Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.raw_text: Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257 (2001)
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.proposition: A modification is therefore necessary to align the parenting schedule with the child’s schooling, stability, and emotional wellbeing, consistent with Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704 (1985), and Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257 (2001).
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.support_reasoning: Rosenthal concerns standards for modifying custody and for removal from the Commonwealth; it does not discuss modifying a parenting schedule specifically to align with a child’s schooling, stability, and emotional wellbeing. The opinion does mention school timing only in remanding for a determination whether the child should finish the current term in one school or start in another, but that is ancillary to relocation and custody, not a general principle that a modification is necessary to align parenting time with school and wellbeing. Thus, citing Rosenthal for that broad proposition overstates its holding and context.
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.relevant_excerpt: “In the absence of agreement, the Probate Court may consider whether it is in Caleb’s best interest to conclude the current school term in Northborough and to begin the next school term in Providence, or transfer to a new school in Providence forthwith.”

Ireland v. Ireland, 428 Mass. 1006 (1998.proposition: Massachusetts law instructs the Court to consider the child’s stability, relationship with each parent, and ongoing educational and social development.
Ireland v. Ireland, 428 Mass. 1006 (1998.support_reasoning: The provided text is not Ireland v. Ireland and does not concern child custody or best-interest-of-the-child standards. It is a criminal speedy-trial decision (Commonwealth v. Amidon and related cases) dealing with Rule 36 calculations and acquiescence to delay. It does not discuss factors such as a child’s stability, relationships with parents, or educational and social development, so it cannot support the cited proposition about Massachusetts custody law.
Ireland v. Ireland, 428 Mass. 1006 (1998.relevant_excerpt: "Consequently, dismissal of the indictments is inappropriate where this defendant has essentially waived his right to a speedy trial by failing to object to any of the delay and, under the particular circumstances of this case, dismissal does not serve ‘the public interest in bringing guilty persons to trial.’ Barry v. Commonwealth, supra at 297."

Vilakazi v. Maxie, 371 Mass. 406 (1976).proposition: Massachusetts law instructs the Court to consider the child’s stability, relationship with each parent, and ongoing educational and social development.
Vilakazi v. Maxie, 371 Mass. 406 (1976).support_reasoning: The opinion reaffirms only the broad Massachusetts standard that child custody decisions are governed by the welfare of the child, considering both present and probable future welfare, and that this lies within the judge’s discretion. It does not articulate a specific requirement that courts must consider the child’s stability, the relationship with each parent, or educational and social development as distinct or enumerated factors. Thus, using this case to support that more detailed, factor-based proposition overstates what the decision actually holds.
Vilakazi v. Maxie, 371 Mass. 406 (1976).relevant_excerpt: In providing for the custody of a minor child, while the feelings and the wishes of the parents should not be disregarded, the happiness and the welfare of the child should be the controlling consideration. It is the duty of the judge to consider the welfare of the child in reference not merely to the present, but also to the probable future, and it is a subject peculiarly within the discretion of the judge.

Felton v. Felton, 383 Mass. 232 (1981).proposition: The guiding principle remains the child’s welfare.
Felton v. Felton, 383 Mass. 232 (1981).support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly frames the governing standard in custody/visitation disputes as the child’s best interests or welfare. In discussing the balance between parents’ religious liberties and restrictions on those liberties, the court repeatedly emphasizes that any limitation must be justified by harm to the child and that the ‘dominating goal’ is serving the child’s best interests, thereby confirming that the child’s welfare is the guiding principle.
Felton v. Felton, 383 Mass. 232 (1981).relevant_excerpt: But the “best interests” of the child are to be promoted, and when the parents are at odds, the attainment of that purpose may involve some limitation of the liberties of one or other of the parents. … If the dominating goal of the enterprise is to serve a child’s best interests, as the cases asseverate (see Vilakazi v. Maxie, supra at 409; cf. G. L. c. 208, § 31 [as to awards of custody])…

Rubin v. Rubin, 77 Mass. App. Ct. 776 (2.raw_text: Rubin v. Rubin, 77 Mass. App. Ct. 776 (2010)
Rubin v. Rubin, 77 Mass. App. Ct. 776 (2.proposition: The guiding principle remains the child’s welfare.
Rubin v. Rubin, 77 Mass. App. Ct. 776 (2.support_reasoning: While this opinion is primarily about evidentiary rulings and adequacy of agency efforts, the court repeatedly frames its analysis in terms of the child’s best interests and welfare, particularly when rejecting remedies that would prioritize correcting agency errors over the child’s situation. The court explicitly states that the focus of termination proceedings is the child’s welfare and upholds the decree by emphasizing what is in Daisy’s best interests, which aligns with the proposition that the guiding principle remains the child’s welfare.
Rubin v. Rubin, 77 Mass. App. Ct. 776 (2.relevant_excerpt: “In any event, even if the department’s handling of the case markedly contributed to the deterioration of the relationship between Daisy and the mother, neither dismissal of the petition (as requested by the mother) nor reversal and remand would be an appropriate remedy. There is no indication that the department acted arbitrarily or irrationally. Furthermore, ‘the proper focus of termination proceedings is the welfare of the child.’ Adoption of Gregory, 434 Mass. at 121. As we explain below, viewed from that perspective there is no basis to disturb the decree.”

Canning v. Juskalian, 33 Mass. App. Ct..raw_text: Canning v. Juskalian, 33 Mass. App. Ct. 202 (1992)
Canning v. Juskalian, 33 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: The guiding principle remains the child’s welfare.
Canning v. Juskalian, 33 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion applies and interprets the Massachusetts Child Support Guidelines, focusing on attribution of income, treatment of subsequent families, and extraordinary visitation expenses. While it discusses concepts like the child’s best interest and parental responsibility, it does not clearly articulate or adopt a general overarching statement that “the guiding principle remains the child’s welfare” as a controlling rule for support determinations. Any concern for the child’s welfare is implicit rather than framed as the guiding legal principle at issue in the case.
Canning v. Juskalian, 33 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “Given the importance which attaches to ‘both parents hav[ing] frequent and continuing association with their child,’ … and the broad recognition of the ‘interests of the non-custodial parent and the child in visiting with each [other],’ … extensive adjustment of a support order to accommodate extended long-distance visitation is generally warranted and in the child’s best interest.”
